creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
inscription:
Signature, Date, Inscription, Stamp

inscribed in plate at top: [CACVM FLAMMIVOMVM OPPRIMIT HERCVLES]
markings: blue stamp on verso, LL: unidentified collector\'s mark, Lugt 1940
provenance: Collector with unidentified mark, Lugt 1940. John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
signed: monogram and date in plate at upper left: [1545 / HSB]
text:
The legendary strongman Hercules was born to the god Zeus and a mortal named Alcmena. This union so incensed Zeus’s wife Hera that she made life almost unbearable for the hero. Her ire resulted in him undertaking a series of tasks, known as the Twelve Labors of Hercules. Sebald Beham challenged his audience’s knowledge of the classical text, engraving three actual labors and nine scenes of Hercules’ exploits before and after his labors.

After Hercules steals Geryon’s cattle, the fire-breathing Cacus steals some cows for himself. Here Hercules punishes him as a cow looks on.
title: Hercules Killing Cacus, From the Labors of Hercules
